2.5. Dispersion Relation and Gap¶

2.5.1. Discrete Beams¶

I define the following beams,

spectDBWC1 = {{1, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}
spectDBWC2 = {{0.5, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}
spectDBWC3 = {{0.1, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}

spectDBC1 = {{-1, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}
spectDBC2 = {{-0.5, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}
spectDBC3 = {{-0.1, -0.6}, {1, 0.1}, {1, 0.6}}

The first thing is to really see that the instability regions are going through the gap in discrete beams case.

Fig. 2.52 MAA solutions for spectra WC1, WC2, WC3. The instability regions go through the gap.

Fig. 2.53 MAA solutions for spectra C1, C2, C3. For real \(\omega\), no complex k is found.

The MZA+ solution can also be found.

Fig. 2.54 MZA+ solution for WC spectra.

Fig. 2.55 MZA+ solution for C spectra. As like before, no instability in k is found.

The MZA- solutions:

Fig. 2.56 MZA- solution for WC spectra.

Fig. 2.57 MZA- solution for C spectra.

So the C spectra have no instabilities in k. I should calculate the instabilities in \(\omega\) for real k.

Fig. 2.58 MAA solution for real k finding complex \(\omega\).

Fig. 2.59 MZA+ solution for real k finding complex \(\omega\).

Fig. 2.60 MZA- solution for real k finding complex \(\omega\).
